item.title: 1.1 Examples
item.description:
Average Rate of Change given an Equation.

Example 1:

Find the average rate of change of the function \(f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 1\) between \(x = 1\) and \(x = 3\).

  1. Calculate \(f(1)\):
\[ f(1) = 1^2 - 2(1) + 1 = 0 \]
  1. Calculate \(f(3)\):
\[ f(3) = 3^2 - 2(3) + 1 = 4 \]
  1. Use the average rate of change formula:
\[ \text{Average Rate of Change} = \frac{f(3) - f(1)}{3 - 1} = \frac{4 - 0}{3 - 1} = 2 \]

So, the average rate of change of the function \(f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 1\) between \(x = 1\) and \(x = 3\) is 2.

item.title: 1.1 Practice
item.description:
MCV4U 1.1 Average Rates of Change

Ex 1

Consider the quadratic function \( f(x) = x^2 + 2x + 1 \).

Question: Find the average rate of change of \( f(x) \) on the interval \([1, 3]\). What is the slope of the secant line, and what is the equation of the secant line in point-slope form?

Solution
  1. \[ f(1) = 1^2 + 2(1) + 1 = 4 \]\[ f(3) = 3^2 + 2(3) + 1 = 16 \]

  2. Find the slope of the secant line: \( m = \frac{f(3) - f(1)}{3 - 1} = \frac{16 - 4}{2} = 6 \)
